title: 115_hr1492
content: The Act titled "Medical Controlled Substances Transportation Act of 2017" requires registration for transporting controlled substances to states where the practitioner is not registered under the Controlled Substances Act for administering substances at locations other than their main place of business or professional practice. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to allow practitioners to transport controlled substances to states where they are not registered for administering at locations other than their main place of business. Practitioners can transport and administer controlled substances at locations other than their main place of business if authorized by a registration issued under specific conditions. The practitioner must be licensed or permitted by the state where the substances are administered, and must limit the time of transport. Practitioners with a registration can transport and administer controlled substances for up to 72 hours, returning any unused substances to their registered location. Records of transportation and administration must be maintained at the practitioner's registered location. The Attorney General may deny or revoke a practitioner's registration based on specified criteria, excluding the exception in subsection 307(c)(1)(B). The Attorney General may deny or revoke a practitioner's registration based on specified criteria, excluding the exception in subsection 307(c)(1)(B). The applicant is not required to present proof of State authorization to administer controlled substances for registration. A registration issued under this subsection will automatically terminate if the practitioner no longer has an active registration under subsection (f) due to revocation, suspension, surrender, or other termination. The term 'registered location' refers to the address on the certificate of registration. The House of Representatives passed the document on July 12, 2017, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
